determines the crystal ﬁeld strength and the lanthanide site,

associated to the activator, all fabricated Eu
ﬁlms display similar emission bands in the PL spectra.
However, the diﬀerences in the symmetry of the lattice site
occupied by the activator or the local crystal environment
provided by the host give rise to the variations observed in the
ﬁne features of the emission spectrum.
performance of the diﬀerent ﬁlms fabricated, we measure the
and 75%, respectively. This group of nanophosphors allows the
comparison of materials with the same crystalline structure but
composition but diﬀerent crystalline structure, that is,
QY values experimentally observed may originate from the
diﬀerent transfer eﬃciencies between the host and the activator
or from the variations in the crystal structure, which aﬀect the
radiative rate of the activator, only rigorous calculations of the
electronic structure of these materials could provide an
ultimate answer for the physical origin of the diﬀerences
found between the experimental eﬃciency values.
To attain eﬃcient and tunable white-light-emitting phosphor
was employed as the red-emitting sublayer and the Dy
as the green sublayer. As depicted by the black solid
emission lines in the blue (483 nm) and yellow (572 nm)
regions of the visible spectrum. By comparing the excitation
a, one can notice that they are almost identical,
which demonstrates the occurrence of energy transfer from the
ions. Layered phosphor coatings were fabricated
by sequential spin coating of nanophosphors. To improve the
adhesion to the substrate (quartz), the phosphor bilayer is
deposited over a thin layer of ZrO
layer improves the uniformity of the nanophosphor ﬁlms
deposited atop, which may originate from the diﬀerent surface
ﬁlm compared to the quartz substrate. To
achieve white-light emission, stacks with a total thickness of
500 nm were prepared, so that full extinction of the
photoexcitation was guaranteed as it would be required if these
coatings are integrated as downshifters in light-emitting
devices. Indeed, our measurements indicate that the PL
intensity increases with the thickness of the ﬁlms up to
nm, meaning that such value of ﬁlm thickness is enough so as
to absorb the complete fraction of the excitation light that is
not reﬂected in the nanophosphor/air interface.
gives rise to porous but continuous ﬁlms in which structural
defects and surface traps present in the as-prepared nanocryst-

layer in the stack responds equally to the thermal treatment,

We determine the absolute values of the ballistic trans-
mittance. The illustrative results attained for a bilayer stack
remains above 70% for the complete visible range, with
oscillations that arise as a result of the optical interference
occurring in the layered stack. The fraction of light absorbed
by the bilayer reaches 70% in the UV range at which the
phosphors of choice are excited, with the remaining light at
these short wavelengths diﬀusely scattered by the disordered
pore network present in the sintered ﬁlms. Hence, although the
